key_points: Colonial Pipeline, the largest fuel pipeline in the U.S., restarted operations following a hacker-induced shutdown.
The shutdown led to widespread gas shortages, panic-buying, and long lines at gas stations across the Southeast.
It will take several days for fuel deliveries to normalize, according to Colonial Pipeline.
The cyberattack did not allow hackers to control pipeline operations, but led to the shutdown to contain the damage.
The restart of the pipeline is expected to address the transportation issue affecting fuel supply to gas stations.
Over half of the gas stations in North Carolina and about half in Georgia and Virginia ran out of fuel.
Incidents of violence and price gouging were reported amid the fuel shortage.
The fuel disruption occurred as Americans are becoming more mobile, especially with pandemic restrictions easing.
Several U.S. agencies relaxed rules to expedite fuel transport via trucks, trains, and ships, despite a national trucker shortage.
The national average price for a gallon of gasoline surpassed $3 for the first time since 2016.
spokespersons: Jamar Gatison (construction worker and Uber Eats driver)
Ron Brown (operator, Ron's Appalachian Trail Shuttles)
Mary Goldburg (T-shirt and promotional products deliverer)
Jeff Lenard (spokesman, National Association of Convenience Stores)
Ryan McNutt (CEO, Society of Independent Gasoline Marketers of America)
